text:
The edges of a clip-path are not properly anti-aliased, whereas edges of normal 
elements are. The following SVG demonstrates the problem:

--- cut here ---
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="iso-8859-1"?>
<!DOCTYPE svg PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD SVG 20000303 Stylable//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/2000/03/WD-SVG-20000303/DTD/svg-20000303-stylable.dtd">
<svg viewBox="0 0 100 100" xml:space="preserve"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
  <defs>
    <path id="path" d="M 11 -9 L 9 11 L -11 9 L -9 -11 Z"/>

    <clipPath id="clip">
      <use xlink:href="#path"/>
    </clipPath>
  </defs>

  <!-- using path to draw: anti-aliased -->
  <g transform="translate(30,50)">
    <use fill="green" xlink:href="#path"/>
  </g>

  <!-- using path to clip: not anti-aliased -->
  <g transform="translate(70,50)">
    <rect clip-path="url(#clip)" fill="red"
          x="-40" y="-40" width="80" height="80"/>
  </g>
</svg>

deweese@apache.org
text:
Clip paths will now be rendered anti-aliased if the clip-path element
has shape-rendering="geometricPrecision".  Otherwise it will continue
to use non-anti-aliased clipping (much faster).
